scripts.comment: It can be argued that Scratch (from which we inherited ASK AND WAIT) should have implemented this as the primitive for interaction in the first place. We won't speculate about why they chose to do what they did, but we've thought about making this change in Snap!. ANSWER TO PROMPT is simpler because you see the prompt in the code at the point where you're using the answer, rather than having to look back in the code to find what the question was.

block-definition.comment: Reports True if the first input string contains the second input string, otherwise false. Comparison is case-independent by default; use USE CASE-INDEPENDENT COMPARISONS to change that.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:text _ conté _ ?

block-definition.comment: Reports the character position (starting from 1) of the beginning of the first input string inside the second input string. If it's not found, reports 0.
block-definition.translations: pt:a posição de _ em _ ca:posició de _ en _

custom-block.l: Enter c to clear the list, or anything else to cancel.

scripts.comment: About 3.2.2.4: It's a little strange having the button you pushed show a speech balloon in the first place. Another solution to speech balloons hidden by the contact list watcher is to put the question in the box where the user will enter the answer. The way to do that is to have the Stage ask the question. Here's an alternative version of ANSWER TO PROMPT:

custom-block.comment: helper procedure for ASK NAME etc.
